Right now we are working toward building our first proof-of-concept modem prototype, which will simply be the modem section of Openmoko's GTA02 phone extracted and separated from the rest of the design and built on a board by itself. It'll be powered from a lab bench power supply emulating the battery and both Calypso UARTs (interfaces for programming, control and data) will be brought out on headers.
We seek to replace Openmoko's triband radio front-end with a quadband one (making a GSM device anything less than quadband means that someone would have to be excluded, and we do not wish to exclude anyone), and this prototype board we currently seek to build will allow us to validate and prove our quadband design before we reuse it as a building block for more complex hardware designs approaching a final product.
We are a non-profit organization (although unfortunately not officially recognized as such yet), and we do not believe in the doctrine of "intellectual property". Absolutely everything we have produced in the past and will produce in the future, including the present family of projects, is in the public domain, free for anyone in the world to use as they see fit without asking us for permission. We apply this principle not only to software, but also to hardware: all design work is being done in public source repositories, and whenever we have a board design ready to be physically produced, we release the finished schematics, BOM, gerber files and editable PCB sources into the public domain via our FTP site. In other words, we create a ready-to-build design, but absolutely do not mind if someone else takes our work and runs with it into commercial production. We want you to "pirate" our work!
Free firmware choices
The Free Software community greatly values diversity and freedom of choice, and free firmware for phones with Calypso baseband processors is no exception. At the present time there is not just one but two independent free software projects seeking to produce fully free and fully functional GSM baseband firmware that can replace the proprietary kind: one is our own FreeCalypso and the other is OsmocomBB. The two free firmware projects have somewhat different focus: OsmocomBB focuses on facilitating GSM hacking and security research, whereas our own FreeCalypso project seeks to produce free firmware for everyday use by ordinary end users.
When we build our own Calypso phones and modems that will run free firmware on the baseband processor, the choice of which free firmware to run remains with the user. While we naturally promote and support our own implementation, there will never be any obstacle to running OsmocomBB (or any other free firmware implementation that may appear in the future) on our hardware.
Our qualifications

The principal developer behind this project has been working toward the goal of a cellular phone free from proprietary software since 2011. Between 2011 and 2013 I gathered (through painstaking and meticulous scavenging) the most critical parts of our extensive collection of hardware documentation and reference source code that is now amassed on our FTP site (it never stops growing though), and since 2013 I've been working on the free firmware project linked above.
But software/firmware work alone can only take us so far: now that the supply of pre-existing phones with the Calypso baseband chipset has been exhausted, it is time for us to build our own hardware with this chipset in order for the world at large to be able to benefit from our work.
In the case of Open Source Hardware development, my experience is that I have designed and built my own SDSL modem that serves my own Internet connection; you can read about that project, download all related design files (released free to the world as always) and see pictures of the gadget here. Thus I consider myself as qualified as anyone else for the job of building phones and modems with a free Calypso baseband.
What we need money for


Our modem design will be based on the one in Openmoko's GTA02 phones. More specifically, we are copying many important aspects from Openmoko's original PCB layout. When we started this crowdfunding campaign at the beginning of April, Openmoko's original PCB layout files seemed to have been irretrievably lost. However, on April 10 we were very pleasantly surprised by Mr. Sean Moss-Pultz, the original founder of Openmoko, who was able to dig up a surviving copy of these files!
Had these PCB layout files not been found, we would have had to recover the layout by reverse engineering (slicing a sacrificial board to reveal and image its inner layers), and that venture would have cost us about $6000. Coming up with a way to cover that high cost was the original reason why we started this crowdfunding campaign, and that cost is what our goal figure has been based on.
However, now that we have recovered the original PCB layout files and don't need to spend $6k on reverse engineering, the campaign goal figure no longer has any significance. Whatever amount we manage to raise, be it small or large, will be used to help the project team - our core team members are currently having a very hard time, and the hardship is expected to last several months. It is very difficult to work on a free software or hardware design project while struggling to survive, so by helping the humans behind the project, you will be helping the project itself.

story:
Every child deserves the chance to fall in love with reading.

–Traveling Stories

Hi! My name is Emily Moberly and I'm the founder of Traveling Stories, a nonprofit organization that is outsmarting poverty one book at a time. An avid reader myself, I was shocked to see so many kids who thought their stories didn't matter and that reading was boring.

I started Traveling Stories in an effort to change their minds! At Traveling Stories we believe that when this happens we'll have a population confident in their self worth and empowered with the critical thinking skills and strong imaginations they need to be able to outsmart poverty in their own communities.

Meet Malikah

Nine-year-old Malika couldn’t sit still long enough to read an entire book when she first came to the Traveling Stories StoryTent three years ago. One week, with help from a volunteer, she discovered the Madeline books by Ludwig Bemelman and couldn’t put them down! This year Malika was reclassified at school from below average to above average in reading. Her mom says this is a direct result of the time she spends reading at the StoryTent every week. Click here to watch Malika's recent review of The Trumpet of the Swan!


Why this campaign is needed ...

Did you know that millions of people in the world can't read?


And it's not just adults, or developing countries ...

32 million Americans can't read and two-thirds of fourth graders in our own country cannot read at grade level. It's ridiculous, right? (US Dept of Education & NAEP)

Living in a world where people cannot read impacts those of us who can read.

Did you know that the U.S. spends about $2 billion of taxpayer money every year on education for kids who repeat grades because of low literacy skills? (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services)

Why does it matter if people can read?

There is a direct correlation between poverty and illiteracy. If we can improve peoples' literacy skills, we can increase their chances of being healthy, productive, contributing members of society, which we believe is a win for everyone! 


Literacy & earnings potential:

Literacy and health:

(Source: UNESCO) 

Our solution:

We refuse to live in a world where people cannot read, so we're building libraries in villages where there are no books & providing free literacy coaching through StoryTents at farmers markers & other publics areas here in the U.S.

We need your help to raise more funds so that we can create more libraries and StoryTents.

What we've done so far:

What we can do with your help: 

With $25,000 we can start 10 StoryTents and 10 world Libraries, allowing us to impact at least 4,000 children and provide more than 200,000 hours of free reading support this year! If we raise more, we can have an even bigger impact!

MyBrary, Our Social Franchise-style Strategy

Our dream is to expand into every country and every state. To do this sustainably, we've created a social franchise-style model called MyBrary that lets people create their own world library or operate their own StoryTent using our model, brand and on-going coaching. Here's a short video about MyBrary:


About our Efficiency:

Among nonprofits, Traveling Stories is incredibly cost-effective. We have low administrative costs (<10%). Besides, all of the costs of our existing libraries and StoryTents are already covered by donors, so 100% of the money raised in this campaign will be used to provide reading support in brand new communities!

Beyond money— we need your help spreading the word

At its heart, Traveling Stories is a grassroots movement driven by parents, teachers and students who want to grow a world of readers. Whether you donate to our campaign or not, you can still help make history.

Ways you can help:

·   Share this campaign on all your social media pages! Ask your friends to share, too!

·  Spread the word about #TravelingStories and our crowdfunding campaign #WorldOfReaders on Facebook, Twitter & Instagram! 

· Visit our resources page for infographics, videos, sample tweets and emails you can use to spread the word about the #WorldOfReaders campaign!

·  Amazon.com customers: Do your shopping at smile.amazon.com to donate a % of all purchases to Traveling Stories

·  Stay connected. Follow Traveling Stories on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram & YouTube to stay up-to-date on the World of Readers movement.

Recognizing your generosity. Thank you!

The work we do changes kids' lives forever. Your donation today makes you a hero in a child's life. Every dollar you give will impact one child, who will learn about your support. We thank you, and so do the children!Here are some of the Thank You notes the kids made to show their gratitude! 

Our campaign in the press:

Fox5 May 4, 2015: http://fox5sandiego.com/2015/05/04/non-profit-teaches-kids-the-power-of-reading/

Bleeding Cool MAY 7, 2015:  http://www.bleedingcool.com/2015/05/07/500-for-your-best-bet-to-pitch-a-comic-to-idw-at-san-diego-comic-con/


Thank you to the companies that made this campaign possible:


Frequently Asked Questions

Are you a non-profit?  Can I write-off my contribution with my taxes? Yes, Traveling Stories is registered as a public 501(c)(3) nonprofit. Contributions to Traveling Stories are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Traveling Stories’ tax ID number is 32-0298884. If you need additional documentation, email us at crowdfunding@travelingstories.org!

How can I get a tax deductible receipt? When you contribute, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution.  This email receipt can be used for tax deductible purposes. For all contributions over $250, you will receive an official receipt for tax-reporting purposes by email after the campaign ends.

How will the funds be used?

The funds will be used to improve Traveling Stories existing literacy programs and to create new libraries and StoryTents.

If donors are already supporting you, why should I help?

To date, we’ve been privileged to have the support of several  generous individuals, corporations, and foundations. But to sustain our organization for the long haul, we need to engage parents and community members. All donations, regardless of the amount, help further our mission and allow us to impact more children. 

How do I start my own library or StoryTent? 

With our new social franchise-style model, MyBrary, we make it possible for you to start a StoryTent or World Library without the hassles of starting your own nonprofit. To learn more about starting a World Library click here: http://travelingstories.org/about-world-libraries. To learn more about starting a StoryTent click here: http://travelingstories.org/start-a-storytent/

Can I donate from outside the USA? Absolutely! Indiegogo only accepts international credit cards, not bank or debit cards. Unfortunately we can’t accept PayPal, so the way to donate internationally is with a credit card.

Is this campaign international? Yes! Our programs are currently in El Salvador, Nicaragua, South Sudan and the Philippines but this funding will allow us to expand to even more countries. We also provide books in the language that the community prefers. To learn more, visit www.travelingstories.org!

What payment methods do you accept? Indiegogo accepts all major credit cards.

Large Contributions - How can I make a contribution over $10,000? The nonprofit payment processor (FirstGiving) that is handling the transactions for this campaign is able to accept direct wire transfers for contributions of $10,000 or more. If you are interested in making a large contribution through a wire transfer to FirstGiving, please contact us at crowdfunding@travelingstories.org. We’ll connect you with a specialist at Indiegogo who will assist you with the contribution transfer process.

Is shipping included? It sure is!

Does international shipping cost extra? Yes, but Indiegogo doesn’t allow us to add any extra shipping to the perks, so it is included in the suggested donation price.

I have more questions. Who do I ask? Please email us at crowdfunding@travelingstories.org! We promise to get back to you with an answer as quickly as possible.


Perks!

story:
Watoto International School (W.I.S) is committed to the holistic development of children with active and creative minds who are compassionate towards others and walking with integrity.

W.I.S currently has classrooms for nursery levels to Primary 4 (P4), however the school needs to expand. It is becoming well-known in the community because of the standard of education it provides the students. Just the other day a girl in P6 from another school came to W.I.S and told the director she and a group of her friends wanted to transfer to W.I.S! What an amazing compliment. Watoto International School is located in Malaba, Uganda, near the border of Kenya. This school is crucial to the area as over half the children are from single-mother homes. These women are struggling to make ends meet, many earning less than $1/day. W.I.S has the land to expand, wanting to put up more classrooms and eventually a dormitory to provide a safe place for vulnerable children. Currently, the main goal is to rebuild the portion of the building, seen on the left in the photograph, which collapsed during a horrific thunderstorm in 2013. The walls were not properly supported so this time around there will be a different construction company working to successfully reconstruct the building therefore creating additional and much-needed classrooms. This will not be an easy feat and this campaign is just step one in the journey to try and raise $20,000 to rebuild.

Please donate and help raise the money to raise the walls to help educate children!

story:
Project Smile Africa - Madagascar? 

Je suis Rija Tahiana, un journaliste et présentateur tv sur une station privée à Madagascar.
J'ai été le seul journaliste choisi pour representer Madagascar dans la couverture médiatique du sommet USA-Africa en 2014 à Washington. J'y ai rencontré une vingtaine d'autres journalistes. Nous avons ensemble décidé de tous faire quelque chose pour notre pays à notre retour. PSA existe déjà au Nigéria et j'ai été vraiment encouragé par les actions là-bas pour créer aussi un Project Smile Africa à Madagascar. D'autres PSA vont être créé dans les autres pays d'Afrique mais chacun gère ses actions. L'objectif commun étant de (re)donner le sourire à l'Afrique, par tous les moyens possibles.

Nos actions

Cette année, nous allons travailler dans l'amélioration de l'éducation au pays. Avec d'autres volontaires, nous avons visité des écoles, les avons rencontré et avons écouté leurs problèmes. Nous avons donné des conseils et avons partagé nos experiences, la base de nos actions. Mais avec notre propre fond, nous avons donné des t-shirts aux 50 meilleurs élèves. Le thème sur leur t-shirt est #Ready2Learn. pour les encourager encore plus, et pour encourager les autres

Beaucoup d'écoles malgaches ont juste le strict minimum; tables et chaises. Nous avons choisi d'aider spécialement un lycée, à 15 km de la capitale: le Lycée Ivato. Pendant notre visite, nous avons retenu que les élèves voudraient bien avoir une bibliothèque et une salle informatique, avec accès internet, pour avoir accès à  toujours plus d'informations, et leur permettre de s'améliorer et de faire des recherches.

Nous leur avons promis de chercher les fonds nécessaires pour cela.

Comment les fonds vont être utilisés ?

Nous avons comme objectif l'achat de 25 ordinateurs pour les 800 élèves du Lycée, ainsi que 200 livres. Nous achèterons autant d'ordinateurs que le fond récolté si jamais nous dépassons l'objectif.

story:
My name is Jennifer McCoy, and I've been a high school art teacher for 20 years. I am National Board Certified and strive to be the most relevant, exciting teacher I can be. I would like to bring in two activist artists next year to run workshops on Social Justice, and teach students how to express themselves through art. East High School is very diverse: There are 48 languages spoken here, and many of our families are recent immigrants from distressed places, having witnessed firsthand the horrors of social injustices. These students especially would benefit from a chance to share and express their experiences in a positive, safe environment. Additionally, many other students are angry about various injustices that either they or friends have experienced; they could also gain  a lot of insight from this workshop. I've had incredible successes over the last 20 years with students who became emotionally invested in art projects – it literally changed their lives because for the first time they feel like they’re being heard.  

This is why I'm on this site, asking for your help. The Center for Documentary Expression and Art has applied for grants in partnership with East HS, but we still need to come up with and additional $7,000 to fund it completely. I’m trying to raise $1,500 of that sum here. 

We plan on bringing in two amazing artist activists, Lily Havey and Ruby Chacon, to each run four-week workshops titled Justice, Memory, Activism for my students. During this experience, students will get the opportunity to discover causes that they feel passionate about, and create powerful, expressive, original artworks based on research and writing (like Haiku, Tanka poems, and journal entries).

Lily Havey is a Japanese-American artist who spent years of her young life in an American internment camp after WWII, and started writing and creating artwork from her vivid memories about it in many years later. She has written a book: Gasa Gasa Girl Goes to Camp, and has had many exhibitions of her paintings shown around the United States. Ruby Chacon has created many expressive and thought provoking murals throughout Utah, Wyoming, Thailand, and Morocco. She believes in uniting and empowering people by communicating through a visual medium.

The workshop will culminate with an exhibit of student artwork at the Salt Lake City Downtown Public Library. I also plan on having the students paint a related mural inside the school.

In addition to crowd funding, I am putting on a benefit concert with local bands (Jonnie Slaughter and the Bipolar Express, and Homo Leviticus) at the Urban Lounge on July 22nd, and am going to be selling T-shirts. The name of the event is Rock Against Injustice, and there is a Facebook page for it where you can buy tickets if you're interested. 

If I don’t raise the entire amount, there are two possibilities. First, our district might come up with the difference needed, and the workshop will continue as planned. If that doesn't happen and we can’t bring in Ms. Havey and Ms. Chacon, then whatever funds are raised will go into my art budget and will be used for the same lesson plans, just without the visiting artists. 

If you would like to contribute but are unable to donate, you could still help me out a great deal by sharing this link on Facebook, or any other social media platform. Thanks so much for taking the time to read this, and remember every bit helps!

Additionally, many other students are angry about various injustices that either they or friends have experienced; they could also gain  a lot of insight from this workshop. I've had incredible successes over the last 20 years with students who became emotionally invested in art projects – it literally changed their lives because for the first time they feel like they’re being heard.  

This is why I'm on this site, asking for your help. The Center for Documentary Expression and Art has applied for grants in partnership with East HS, but we still need to come up with and additional $7,000 to fund it completely. I’m trying to raise $1,500 of that sum here. 

We plan on bringing in two amazing artist activists, Lily Havey and Ruby Chacon, to each run four-week workshops titled Justice, Memory, Activism for my students. During this experience, students will get the opportunity to discover causes that they feel passionate about, and create powerful, expressive, original artworks based on research and writing (like Haiku, Tanka poems, and journal entries).

Lily Havey is a Japanese-American artist who spent years of her young life in an American internment camp after WWII, and started writing and creating artwork from her vivid memories about it in many years later. She has written a book: Gasa Gasa Girl Goes to Camp, and has had many exhibitions of her paintings shown around the United States. Ruby Chacon has created many expressive and thought provoking murals throughout Utah, Wyoming, Thailand, and Morocco. She believes in uniting and empowering people by communicating through a visual medium.

The workshop will culminate with an exhibit of student artwork at the Salt Lake City Downtown Public Library. I also plan on having the students paint a related mural inside the school.

In addition to crowd funding, I am putting on a benefit concert with local bands (Jonnie Slaughter and the Bipolar Express, and Homo Leviticus) at the Urban Lounge on July 22nd, and am going to be selling T-shirts. The name of the event is Rock Against Injustice, and there is a Facebook page for it where you can buy tickets if you're interested. If I don’t raise the entire amount, there are two possibilities. First, our district might come up with the difference needed, and the workshop will continue as planned. If that doesn't happen and we can’t bring in Ms. Havey and Ms. Chacon, then whatever funds are raised will go into my art budget and will be used for the same lesson plans, just without the visiting artists. 

If you would like to contribute but are unable to donate, you could still help me out a great deal by sharing this link on Facebook, or any other social media platform. Thanks so much for taking the time to read this, and remember every bit helps!

story:
Learning Center Project Summary

In the immediate future, Helping Hands Around the World plans to provide a school for underserved children in Biara, Nigeria.  Over the course of the last few years, this part of the world has fallen into increasingly abject poverty.  The average family in the region lives on less than $1 per day.  This is a region where 65% of children receive no primary education, because their families cannot afford to send them to school.  As a result, the cycle of local poverty and poor educational opportunity is deepening.  Today, many children in Ogoniland, Nigeria, do not have an equivalent access to educational opportunities as do their peers in other parts of Nigeria.  A recent research survey in Ogoniland revealed that 40% of Ogoni children do not have any primary education, 60% of Ogoni children do not have access to secondary education, 75% of children do not have college education, and 90% of adults do not have full-time employment.  The lack of access to basic educational facilities and gainful employment is of course related, and it reinforces a continual cycle of deepening poverty in the region -- poor families unable to afford school fees, books, uniforms and shoes for their children produce future generations with access only to more of the same, or worse.  To further worsen the already bad situation, due to a regional teacher strike in the area, there was no schooling in the area at all last year.

To begin to address this situation, we are proposing a Learning Center, the Dookue Memorial School, to improve access to a better quality of education for the children of Biara, Ogoniland and build foundations for a better future.  The name of the school honors Chief Dookue Naanee.

The Dookue Memorial School is named for a man who valued education.  Though he did not complete high school, Chief Dookue Naanee knew the value of education.  He helped many families, in Biara, to invest in their children by paying school fees for those children to go to elementary and secondary school.  He even had the opportunity to help with providing funds for college bound students. Chief Dookue was a farmer and made his money from what he produced from his land.  He had five children of his own and all graduated from high school and had opportunities to go to college.  This man was my father.  He had knowledge that went far beyond his education.  He was widely respected by the community he lived in and by the neighboring towns surrounding Biara. Though my father has passed away, before he died his last words to me was to "take care of the children."  I believe this project is the epitome of how he felt about children and education.  Since education was very important to him this project goes hand in hand with the support he gave all of his life.  Being his eldest son, I have the utmost respect for all he has done and this school would be a great way to carry on his legacy of making sure each child should have the opportunity to receive an education.

The Learning Center will permit a generation of youth in the area who are able to eat healthy meals at the school to guarantee that they are prepared for the learning process, and to provide an atmosphere where the same children are able to learn and develop habits for continuing education.  The learning center already has one unimproved building in place, as well as a small staff of teachers and administrators who are ready for the program to launch.  Any funds obtained in this campaign will be used for teacher salary, nutrition for the students, desks, chairs, educational infrastructure, supplies, and a small number of computers so that the children can be exposed to, and benefit from, high-tech learning tools.

Description of Existing Site, and Plans for the Future

The land and some unimproved structures has been donated for use to the school.  The students of the learning center will have access to  classrooms, a computer lab, and a library.  Each classroom will have one teacher, and one assistant teacher.  In each classroom, the student body will consist of 30 children between the ages of four and six years.  One kitchen staff and the two assistant teachers will cook, make sure all of the children are fed, and perform cleanup duties.  There will be one administrator and one office staffer to keep and maintain records, to promote the vision and mission of the school, and to provide backup for other duties as needed.  The facility has a kitchen and several classrooms, with bathrooms on the first floor.  On the second floor there are eight rooms and two bathrooms for classrooms and storage areas, with an extra room allowing for future expansion of capacity to serve more youth in the area, once the program is in place and fully staffed.

The computer lab will house computer systems so that the students are able to learn, communicate, and familiarize themselves with technological learning tools, sometimes for the first time.  The Learning Center will aid in educating and empowering the outh so that the cycle of poverty asa by-product of educational lack can come to an end.

The foundation that the Learning Center will set is the first and most important step towards the transformation of an area that is universally affected by poverty.  Children in the area regularly go from morning until night without food or any kind of nutrition.  Helping Hands recognizes this as a major roadblock of the learning process, and because of that, will have a program in place that will allow for students to receive breakfast and lunch during school days.  This will ensure that our efforts have the most effective possible results, and that the students are properly equipped for a learning environment.

What We Need 

Our goal is for $30,000. The funds will be going for suppliess and equipment as well as funding the salaries for teachers and administrative staff.  Below is a breakdown of the items we will need.                                                                                  .

  • 40 Student desks
  • 40 chairs
  • Blackboard
  • Chalk
  • Whiteboard
  • Generator
  • Refrigerator
  • 22 Computers
  • 3 Printers
  • 20 ipads
  • Office supplies (office desks, tables, chairs; paper, pencil, paper clips; file folder, etc.)
  • Staff salaries for 1 year (4 teachers/aides, 2 administrative office staff $125/month), $9,000
  • Kitchen supplies (pots, pans, trays, etc.) 

What you Get

  1. For a $25.00 contribution - A Helping Hands Around the World wristband.
  2. For a $100.00 contribution - A Helping Hands Around the World T-Shirt.
  3. For a $1000 contribution - A Donor sign with your name on it displayed in the School.

We are sure we will reach our goal but if we don't, any contributions received will still be used for the a scaled down version of our project.  This may involve serving less students and hiring less staff with the anticipation that we will be able to increase services at a later time.

The Impact

Helping Hands Around the World is a nonprofit humanitarian organization dedicated to working with families, children, and the global community in order to allow the children of the world to reach their full potential through economic and educational empowerment.  The goal of our organization is to increase access to quality education in underserved areas, to promote educational wellness, and to empower positive change in communities.  The mission of Helping Hands Around the World is to promote economic empowerment by provisioning funds, goods and services in any part of the world seeking support and financial assistance, to provide access to education to children and families through community-based solutions, and to promote positive change to communities based on awareness of the responsibility to the rest of the world,

Your contribution to the Learning Center will make what was impossible, possible.  You will have the opportunity to help children who would otherwise not have the opportunity to go to school. These children would live in despair and without hope.  This is our chance to help these families break the cycle of poverty.  Your contribution would allow these children to go to a school locally thus providing a great relief for the families who are unable to afford the expense of school let alone the cost of other expenses like food and sometimes room and board.  You will be giving these children a chance to compete with the rest of the world.  The future of our children depends on all of us to help make the future of the world and of our children brighter.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask friends, family and co-workers to get the word out and make some noise about our project.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools, social media including but not limited to facebook.
  • Visit our website, www.helpinghandsaroundtheworld.com, for more information and updates on the project.

story:
Qui nous sommes

Nous sommes Kira Burundi (www.kiraburundi.org), un jeune organisme sans but lucratif voué à appuyer les enfants de la rue dans la ville de Ngozi, au Burundi. À l’écoute des besoins de ces enfants oubliés et sous-estimés, nous nous engageons à travailler pour qu’ils regagnent estime et dignité en appuyant leurs projets et leurs rêves, et en les plaçant dans des conditions favorables à leur épanouissement.

Depuis 2012, nos actions ont permis :

-  De nourrir et d’accompagner hebdomadairement plus de 50 jeunes de la rue à travers des activités sportives et des activités d’écoute;

-  De permettre à 10 adolescents qui vivaient dans la rue de réaliser leur rêve d’avoir un emploi, soit de travailler dans une station de lavage de voitures pour sortir du cycle de la mendicité et apprendre à s’autonomiser;

-  De réintégrer 12 jeunes enfants de la rue dans un foyer stable et leur permettre de retourner sur le banc de l’école. Ce qui leur ouvre les portes pour un avenir meilleur.

Notre projet

Notre projet est de réintégrer, au cours de l’année 2015, 10 autres jeunes enfants de la rue dans des familles d’accueil afin de leur redonner un milieu de vie décent et leur permettre de retourner sur les bancs d’école, ce qui est le rêve de tous ces enfants.

Le principe de fonctionnement est relativement simple : une famille accepte d’accueillir un enfant de la rue chez elle, de l’aimer et de subvenir à ses besoins de base comme l’un de ses propres enfants. En échange de ce don, notre organisme donne à la famille une vache ou des chèvres (selon le besoin), ce qui permet à cette famille d’améliorer globalement sa situation financière et alimentaire. Ainsi, l’enfant intègre un milieu familial qui bénéficie d’une certaine stabilité. Kira Burundi se charge des démarches pour inscrire l’enfant à l’école publique, et pourvoit parfois aux besoins de l’enfant en matière de matériel scolaire, selon les moyens de la famille.

Les bénévoles de Kira Burundi sur le terrain s’assurent que les enfants sont bien traités dans les familles et que les familles et les enfants s’adaptent bien à leur nouvelle situation.

Mais ce n’est pas tout! Selon le principe du donner au suivant, bien présent dans la tradition burundaise, le premier-né de la vache ou des chèvres données à la famille sera redonné à l’organisme. Cet animal sera donné à une nouvelle famille qui aura accepté d’accueillir un enfant. Cette famille s’engagera elle aussi à redonner le premier-né de ces animaux à l’organisme, et ainsi de suite. Ainsi, à terme, un seul enfant réintégré permettra d’en réintégrer un, puis deux, puis trois, etc.

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous avons besoin de 10 000 $ pour réintégrer ces 10 enfants de la rue. Les démarches de réintégration d’un enfant coûtent, en tout, 1000 $ par enfant. Ce coût inclut l’achat de la vache ou des chèvres et leur transport jusqu’au domicile familial (850 $), les démarches de réinscription à l’école (50 $), les démarches légales pour la signature du contrat avec la famille d’accueil (50$) et l’achat du matériel scolaire pour les enfants pour la première année d’école (50 $).

Les bénévoles de Kira Burundi qui assurent le bon déroulement des démarches sur le terrain ne sont pas rémunérés; ils effectuent toutes ces tâches gratuitement, avec la conviction de réellement changer le monde et avec le sourire des enfants et des familles comme seul salaire.

La presse en parle:

http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/kira-burundi-la-gr...

http://plus.lapresse.ca/screens/13caae27-be9e-42f9-9cbb-4556aa5240f1|_0.html


D'autres façons d'aider

Vous êtes intéressés, mais ne pouvez pas donner?  Voici comment m’aider :

- Diffuser cette annonce sur les réseaux sociaux;
- Utilisez les outils de partage Indiegogo!

Si les fonds amassés ne sont pas suffisants pour réaliser ce projet, 100 % du montant recueilli sera remis à un organisme du Burundi qui vient en aide aux enfants de la rue de la ville de Ngozi(www.kiraburundi.org).

story:
I am so excited to announce that I am in the beginning stages of starting a Nonprofit for mentoring young adults/kids involved in the music scene!!

The money raised will go towards the start up of this organization that will provide these incredible young adults/kids with the opportunity to experience a bond with mentors that will provide them with a new understanding of love, worth, and healthy relationship/fellowship.

The cost to start a non profit includes submitting all necessary paperwork needed to obtain 501 (C) 3 status. I will be working directly with the Center for Nonprofit Management in Nashville TN, which provides consultation as well as workshops. I will also be seeking legal help to ensure all process' are handled correctly and looking into training for our mentors. We are going to be working with a mobile application developer as well to produce an app where everyone involved in Beneath The Skin will be able to communicate with one another. It will have important dates, training videos, and resources by State/City. Your support is much appreciated as this need is great and these young adults/kids deserve this care and attention.

story:
The AIAA Club of RAHS

We are a dedicated group of high school students aspiring to become aeronautical and aerospace engineers. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Aeronautics (AIAA) is our parent organization, and Raisbeck Aviation High School (RAHS) is our educational institution.
We are competing in the Team America Rocketry Challenge (TARC). Unfortunately, rockets aren't free. We need your help to design, build and test multiple iterations of our rocket to prepare for competition in April.

What We Need 

Testing
We need $585 to gather materials, design, and test our first rockets.
Competition
We need $195 to build our final rocket, and compete. If we make it to the finals, we will need at least $12,610 to cover travel costs. 
If we do not meet our goal of $13,390, the money raised will still go towards competing in TARC. Similarly, if we do not make it to finals, the remaining money raised toward transportation costs will be put towards next year's competition. 

What You Get

Claim naming rights to a rocket, receive exclusive access to our footage from competition, and add your logo to the outside of a rocket payload when you support our cause. 

The Impact

Currently 10% of aerospace and defense workers are eligible to retire and that percentage is predicted to rapidity grow. 

By supporting the AIAA Club of RAHS, you give students an opportunity to explore and learn about rocketry, aerospace, and engineering. Your contributions assist in the development of many students' futures, and inspire them to select a career path in the aerospace industry. 

Risks & Challenges

While we are building our rockets, we are bound to run into certain challenges. 
Some components of the rocket system may not work after transporting for competition. We are hoping that with your support, we will have enough back up materials to ensure the success of the rocket. 
Dates are tentative since weather is a large factor to launching rockets. We'll try to launch the rockets following our planned timeline.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word with your friends, family and coworkers! If you have experience with model rocketry we would love your support! We could always use more mentors. Feel free to email the team at rahsaiaa@gmail.com for more information.
story_txt:
The AIAA Club of RAHS
We are a dedicated group of high school students aspiring to become aeronautical and aerospace engineers. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Aeronautics (AIAA) is our parent organization, and Raisbeck Aviation High School (RAHS) is our educational institution.
We are competing in the Team America Rocketry Challenge (TARC). Unfortunately, rockets aren't free. We need your help to design, build and test multiple iterations of our rocket to prepare for competition in April.
 
What We Need 

Testing
We need $585 to gather materials, design, and test our first rockets.
Competition
We need $195 to build our final rocket, and compete. If we make it to the finals, we will need at least $12,610 to cover travel costs. 
If we do not meet our goal of $13,390, the money raised will still go towards competing in TARC. Similarly, if we do not make it to finals, the remaining money raised toward transportation costs will be put towards next year's competition. 

What You Get
Claim naming rights to a rocket, receive exclusive access to our footage from competition, and add your logo to the outside of a rocket payload when you support our cause. 
    The Impact
Currently 10% of aerospace and defense workers are eligible to retire and that percentage is predicted to rapidity grow.  By supporting the AIAA Club of RAHS, you give students an opportunity to explore and learn about rocketry, aerospace, and engineering. Your contributions assist in the development of many students' futures, and inspire them to select a career path in the aerospace industry. 
    Risks & Challenges

While we are building our rockets, we are bound to run into certain challenges. 
Some components of the rocket system may not work after transporting for competition. We are hoping that with your support, we will have enough back up materials to ensure the success of the rocket. 
Dates are tentative since weather is a large factor to launching rockets. We'll try to launch the rockets following our planned timeline.

    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word with your friends, family and coworkers! If you have experience with model rocketry we would love your support! We could always use more mentors. Feel free to email the team at rahsaiaa@gmail.com for more information.

story:
Somos ROULT 4403

Somos un equipo de robotica participando en FIRST Robotics Competition creado en el 2012 por estudiantes y profesores del ITESM C.L. apasionados por la tecnología y la robótica. En agosto empezamos con el objetivo de ganar el mundial y para lograr esto trabajamos estos 7 meses intensamente, algunas noches nos quedamos a dormir en la escuela y finalmente construimos el mejor robot del mundo, alias la Traviesa.

El equipo ha ganado los siguientes premios:

  • All Star Rookie Award ; por haber sido el mejor novato en la competencia del 2012
  • Highest Rookie Seeding Award 2012: por ser el novato que califico mas alto en la competencia
  • Coopertition Award 2012: Por haber promocionado y demostrado el juego limpio
  • Entrepeneurship Award 2012: por tener el mejor plan de negocios de la competencia
  • Regional Semifinalist 2014: Por haber llegado a las semifinales en la competencia
  • Regional Finalist 2015: Por ser finalista en la competencia de este año

Tras haber quedado en segundo lugar en la etapa regional de México, el equipo busca asistir a otro evento regional para buscar el pase al mundial tan anhelado por nosotros. Estamos muy entusiasmados por asistir al segundo regional porque con esto lograremos el pase al mundial, al cual vamos a ir a ganar.

Tú como patrocinador estarás ayudando a más de treinta estudiantes de preparatoria a lograr sus sueños: ganar el mundial de robótica. Ya tenemos el mejor robot del mundo. Solo nos falta tu apoyo.

El registro al evento cuesta 4,000 dólares

El camión que nos llevará a nosotros y a Traviesa al munidal cuesta 7,000 dólares

El hotel en el que nos hospedaremos cuesta 4,000 dólares

Ayúdanos!!! Nos falta tu ayuda!!!!

Recompensas:

Si donas  10 dls, te mencionaremos en Redes Sociales .

Si donas 20 dls, te pondremos como fundador platino en nuestra página web. (Y las recompensas anteriores)

Si donas 100 dls, haremos porras con tu nombre en la competencia y te enviaremos el video. (y las recompensas anteriores)

Si donas  200 dls, pondremos tu nombre o el de tu empresa en nuestras cachuchas que llevaremos puestas al regional de las cuales recibiras una.   (y las recompensas anteriores).

Si donas 500 dls, haremos los uniformes con tu nombre/logo y te enviaremos  (y las recompensas anteriores)

Si donas 1,000 dls, pondremos tu logo/nombre en el robot (y las recompensas anteriores)

Contamos con tu apoyo. !!!Vamos juntos al regional!!!

En caso de no completar la meta, los 30 integrantes haremos un video de agradecimiento a todos ustedes , y usaremos el dinero para la siguiente temporada.

story:
What is this About?

My name is Celeste Myers and I've been heart-linked to Pell River Primary School in Cauldwell, Jamaica  for over 15 years. Cauldwell is a mountainous area off the beaten tourism path about 45 minutes from Negril.  A friend and I discovered it while riding with a taxi driver who needed to stop there to pick up his child. After meeting the children and the teachers, I was hooked. I’ve been going back ever since…rarely empty-handed.

The classrooms desperately need new desks and chairs.  The desks, seating two to three children, are old, wooden, and unfinished which are splinter-prone to the busy hands both playing and writing on them.  Also, there is no convenience of air conditioning, regular  equipment or furniture upgrades, cafeteria, refrigerator, or hot water (typically, lukewarm or cool).

A School Teacher Request

During my visit in October 2014, I asked my school teacher friend what are the main things needed for the school.  She immediately responded, “Individual desks and chairs.” In addition, I witnessed and participated with the kitchen ladies hand-washing over 100 plastic plates and cups every day!  The school has no dishwasher and is eco-friendly; removing Styrofoam plates several years ago to help preserve the environment.  So I added a solar hot water heater to the list.

I told her I would do my best to get funding for this request; thus, choosing crowdfunding.  The school teacher emailed me the estimates which converted to over $10,000 USD for all of the items.  The itemized estimate includes:

  • 105 desks ($4,225)
  • 105 metal chairs ($3,480)
  • Solar water heater w/installation ($1,040)
  • One (1) 4-drawer filing cabinet  ($175)
  • Jamaican sales tax on furniture ($1,200)
  • Tax on solar water heater ($171 - 16.50% GCT)
  • Crowdfunding and any pay pal fees (my addition)

Your Dollar Counts

Over the years, my friends and colleagues have pooled funds to purchase school supplies, student uniforms, toiletries (toothbrushes, toothpaste, soap deodorant, etc.) clothing, cash gifts to teachers, and a freezer for the small kitchen. And the gratitude for these items were as if we contributed thousands of dollars.

Your contribution to this project will literally change and enhance the learning environment for both the children and the teachers.  This can easily happen with 10 people giving $1,000 each, 20 giving $500, 100 giving $100 or 10,000 giving a $1.  Every dollar gets us closer to new desks, chairs, and hot water!

Distribution Plan

Once the funding goal is reached, $1,200 will immediately be sent to the school teacher via MoneyGram for the solar water heater installation.  My plan is to hand-deliver the remaining amount to the vendor in Jamaica supplying the desks.  And also take pictures.

Remember, no contribution is too small. Thank you in advance for making desks, chairs and hot water a reality!  Please forward this campaign to others to join us in making this happen for Pell River Primary School.

story:
• Talented violinist Arevik , who has been studding  in Vienna’s  Bach Music School  since  September 2014,  needs financial support  to continue her  education. That help is needed for her to be able to participate in Bram’s  international Competition in September 1th, ; obtain her own  violine  with proper sonorous temper and  to  have the  chance  to prepare  properly the competition program  during June to September months  with her  professors and other musicians in Vienna  in  Linz  summer school.    
  •     
  • Arevik’s tuition fees in 2014/15 where covered by Bach School ,  which   provided her with a full scholarship also greatly  supported  by Prof. Georg Hamanne, who in addition to professional help provided her with fanatical and organizational support as per his capabilities. 

  •
  • Arevik was born in 1998 in Yerevan.  The first musical education she  received at the age of 4, by her violinist mother, Mariam Ivanyan.  At the age of 12, studied at the Tchaikovsky Music School in Conservatory professor Artashes Mkrtchyan's class.  In 2014 was admitted to the Vienna’s Musical  School after Bach  school , Professor Georg Haman’s class .

  •     

  • Since the age  of  5 ,  she participated in several national and international competitions and won several awards, including  Stradivarius founded Competition in  Italian city Kremona where she took the second  prize.. 
  •     
  • Arevik took master classes in Boston by  Longy  and  New England  conservatoires’ professor Mark Lakirovich ,  In Vienna’s Music Univercity by Prof. G.Hamannits,  Zurich’s  Arts University Prof. Koh Gabriel Kameda, Hochschule für Musik Detmold’s   Prof. Diemut Poppen.      

  •      

  • She had solo performances in the United States, Italy, and Austria.  She participated also in numerous concerts as part of the ensemble and symphony orchestras including Vienna’s Symphony Youth Orchestra.

  • At the moment helping Arevik  is extremely important and necessary. She  is surrounded by a very good and positive atmosphere, which certainly contributed to her career growth . She  should be given the opportunity to demonstrate   all her  talent and  that should be  done by her  hard work in 3-4 months.  Arevik certainly will prove that each your input is important, and  her play’s will fill people’s life’s with  happiness and kindness .

story:
Engineers Without Boarders (EWB) is an organization based in the USA that is committed to improving the quality of life for less fortunate people all over the world. There are currently over 12,000 students, faculty and professionals that live and work all over the USA who are members of the organization. Since its start in 2005 the Marquette chapter of EWB has focused most of its efforts in small villages in Guatemala who need better access to electricity and pedestrian bridges to help make transportation possible and easier during the rain season. This specific fundraising campaign will help nearly 400 people located in a village near the Patio Bol River in Guatemala. The people in this area during three to four months out of the year have their access to health care, education, work, and other things cut off because the water levels rise to heights that don’t allow them to safely cross the river. EWB-Marquette feels that everybody should have access to these things at all times, so we are going to build this pedestrian bridge to give them access to these things year round.  

As the people in the villages of Guatemala need and appreciate our help doing these projects that we as engineers love, we need and will greatly appreciate your help in a form of donation or by simply spreading the word about EWB-Marquette to your friends and families. Our goal is to pay for two Marquette students to go on the next EWB-Marquette trip to Guatemala. We have estimated the cost for each student to attend be $1500, so our total fund raising goal will be $3000. The cost of each student includes their travel for the trip, food and shelter during their stay, as well as the tools and supplies they will need to build the bridges. Below is a list of really cool gifts that we will be giving away based on the amount you donate to our campaign:

$10 - A personalized shout out from the official EWB Milwaukee Twitter page.

$15 – A special thank you card signed by the entire EWB-Marquette team.

$25 – Grab bag of authentic Guatemalan goodies

$100 – Dress like the crew and get 2 authentic EWB-Marquette t-shirts.

$300 – Gets you the opportunity to have your name or your company name etched into a rock that will be used to build the bridge

All of our engineering trips have been great experiences for all people involved from those who volunteer to the natives who live in the villages. Your donation and support makes you apart of the EWB-Marquette family and you too will feel great about your contribution and impact you make for our campaign. Our trips have been of great success and after the completion of each one we are on the look out for the next way we can make an impact. There are things we all take for granted sometimes because we have access to them at all times. We have modes of transportation that allow us to go through our daily life routine regardless of the type of weather there is outside. Unfortunately the people who live in these villages lives have been controlled by what mother nature throws at them. With of the help of EWB-MU and your donation this will no longer be an issue for our friends in Guatemala. Please keep up with EWB-Marquette on Facebook EWB-Marquette and Twitter @EWB_Marquette follow us and stay updated on our trip and future projects.

The following is a reflection on EWB-Marquette from a past participant:

"I joined EWB-Marquette in 2007 as a Spanish and Speech Pathology Major and was active over the next few years as a student and professional (cultural) mentor in the Nueva Providencia Project in Guatemala. 

"Throughout my time working with student engineers, professional engineers, the community members of Nueva Providencia and the people of Guatemala, I learned so, so, so much. My experiences through EWB Marquette not only shaped my career, but my relationships, my world view, my values and my character. I gained practical knowledge about electrical wiring, and was extremely challenged by my role as an interpreter - not just from English to Spanish, but from engineer jargon, to layman's terms English, to layman's terms Spanish and then to Kaqchikel, the Mayan  language that was primary for a large portion of the Nueva Providencia community. I learned the rich, painstaking and yet resilient history of Guatemala and its people. I developed interpersonal skills, and was presented with the opportunity to be a part of a truly interdisciplinary team of Guatemalans, engineers and advocates. 

"Most significantly to me, the community of Nueva Providencia, which I came to know only through the mission of EWB Marquette, has molded who I am and who strive to become."

- Ellyn McNamara

story:
A group of 31 students who attend Burkevale Protestant Public School in Penetanguishene Ontario Canada, are trying to raise the funds needed to help them get to the  Atlantic Festival of Music in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
The group, which is made up of students from grades 6 to 8 are extremely talented and dedicated individuals that have been working exceptionally hard, and devoting a tremendous amount of time to  prepare themselves for this festival. They practice during regular school, but also during recess, lunch hours, and often perform at local retirement/nursing homes, and other similar venues to not only polish their skills, but to also provide a fun and upbeat musical experience for people that are unable to attend outside events like this.
The group is led by their music teacher Mrs. Gilchrist, who strives to introduce the students to music at a very early age, and fosters them right through until graduation. She has an exceptional teaching method, and her passion for music is contagious, and really helps to inspire the students.
The students are also extremely lucky to have a  volunteer named Blake Smith. Mr. Smith is a retired high school music teacher that devotes a tremendous amount of his free time to help the students hone their music skills, which is often there during lunch hours, but also at local concerts arranged by Mr. Smith.
He also opens his home to a small group of students 3 days a week from 7am - 8am before school  starts. He does this to not only help the students achieve the best possible results, but also because he feels that music is a very important component of life, and that the early exposure to the positive influence of music will help shape the children's overall growth.
The Atlantic Festival of Music is an opportunity for the students to meet, and compete against other schools from across Canada. It allows them to see some of the best talent in the industry, and learn from some of the best music teachers and adjudicator's in the country. It also gives them the opportunity to meet other students from Canada, and make new friendships and share new experiences in a safe and positive environment.
The total cost of the trip is almost $32,000.00, which covers festival participation fees, travel and accommodation. The bus drive is just over 18 hours, so to save money on accommodation, the students are travelling non-stop both ways,  and will sleep and eat all meals on the bus instead of paying for a hotel on along the way. The students have been trying everything to raise as much money as possible to help alleviate the financial strain on their parents, but in an area with significant economic downturn, and job loss,  it has been very tough to raise money despite their best efforts.
Through prize raffles, concerts, bake sales, corporate donations, and other community events, the students have raised a some of the funds required, but still need approximately $5,000.00 more to hit the mark. This is why we are turning to the Indiegogo community, in the hopes that you can help the students raise the money needed to get to this once and a lifetime event being held  in one of the most oldest and musically diverse regions of the country.  The students will also have an opportunity to see some of the earliest, and most historically significant sites in all of Canada, which for some students, may be their only opportunity.
Any help that you can provide with our fundraising effortst  will be greatly appreciated by all!!
story_txt: A group of 31 students who attend Burkevale Protestant Public School in Penetanguishene Ontario Canada, are trying to raise the funds needed to help them get to the  Atlantic Festival of Music in Halifax, Nova Scotia.The group, which is made up of students from grades 6 to 8 are extremely talented and dedicated individuals that have been working exceptionally hard, and devoting a tremendous amount of time to  prepare themselves for this festival. They practice during regular school, but also during recess, lunch hours, and often perform at local retirement/nursing homes, and other similar venues to not only polish their skills, but to also provide a fun and upbeat musical experience for people that are unable to attend outside events like this.The group is led by their music teacher Mrs. Gilchrist, who strives to introduce the students to music at a very early age, and fosters them right through until graduation. She has an exceptional teaching method, and her passion for music is contagious, and really helps to inspire the students.The students are also extremely lucky to have a  volunteer named Blake Smith. Mr. Smith is a retired high school music teacher that devotes a tremendous amount of his free time to help the students hone their music skills, which is often there during lunch hours, but also at local concerts arranged by Mr. Smith. He also opens his home to a small group of students 3 days a week from 7am - 8am before school  starts. He does this to not only help the students achieve the best possible results, but also because he feels that music is a very important component of life, and that the early exposure to the positive influence of music will help shape the children's overall growth.The Atlantic Festival of Music is an opportunity for the students to meet, and compete against other schools from across Canada. It allows them to see some of the best talent in the industry, and learn from some of the best music teachers and adjudicator's in the country. It also gives them the opportunity to meet other students from Canada, and make new friendships and share new experiences in a safe and positive environment.The total cost of the trip is almost $32,000.00, which covers festival participation fees, travel and accommodation. The bus drive is just over 18 hours, so to save money on accommodation, the students are travelling non-stop both ways,  and will sleep and eat all meals on the bus instead of paying for a hotel on along the way. The students have been trying everything to raise as much money as possible to help alleviate the financial strain on their parents, but in an area with significant economic downturn, and job loss,  it has been very tough to raise money despite their best efforts. Through prize raffles, concerts, bake sales, corporate donations, and other community events, the students have raised a some of the funds required, but still need approximately $5,000.00 more to hit the mark. This is why we are turning to the Indiegogo community, in the hopes that you can help the students raise the money needed to get to this once and a lifetime event being held  in one of the most oldest and musically diverse regions of the country.  The students will also have an opportunity to see some of the earliest, and most historically significant sites in all of Canada, which for some students, may be their only opportunity.Any help that you can provide with our fundraising effortst  will be greatly appreciated by all!!

story:
We're looking to help cycling reach it's full potential.    

My name is Ryan Aulton, I am co-owner of Pleasant Cyclery in beautiful Gainesville FL and I’m the Executive Director of the newly formed not-for-profit, The Freewheel Project.  We are starting a grassroots campaign to support the culture of cycling in all its forms in our community and beyond.  We are an ambitious group on the verge of making big changes in the way cycling is perceived as a form of transportation, tourism, exercise, and sport.

In 2009 I co-opened Pleasant Cyclery on a bare bones budget and have had the best time ever since.  It’s hard to express the joy I feel being able to work with “the greatest machine ever made” and to form the important personal relationships within such an amazing community and culture.  It’s also given me a unique insight into the problems cycling faces in our community.  I’ve found the biggest setbacks are a lack of education, accessibility, and infrastructure. 

My goal has always been to provide a public service, but the opportunities to step away from Pleasant Cyclery never presented themselves. Two years ago, I began to notice a tremor in my left hand.  Six months later, coinciding with the birth of my son, Daniel Matthew, I was diagnosed with early onset Parkinson’s disease at age 32.  Although my wrenching has gotten a bit slower, I’ve been very fortunate to have a tremor dominate form of the disease, which is less aggressive in progression and manageable for the foreseeable future. The combination of these major life changes has given me a new outlook on life and has inspired me to really enjoy my life, and try to spread joy everyday.  And what I enjoy the most is my family, the bicycle, and the culture it fosters.  I began to work on a plan to create a long-term resource for the community that would be sustainable, and cater to solving the problems that face the culture of cycling.

So, with a little help from my friends, I present to you…

The Freewheel Project.

The Freewheel Project is a combination of several things, but it all focuses around our 12,200 sq. ft. historic warehouse on 2.7 acres in the SoMa district in downtown Gainesville.  After several months of negotiations and sleepless nights, we successfully leased this structure for 10 years at a generous rate. Further, our lease granted us the ability to sublease the nearly 9,000 sq. ft. of space not planned for The Freewheel Project.  After initial renovations, the revenue from the subleases will completely subsidize The Freewheel Project's rent, insurance, and utilities.  This will allow us to operate a low cost, education-based bike shop, a bike collective, and classroom (see the list below for details) in 3,500 square feet of space, pay a full time bike mechanic, and run a slew of initial community outreach programs for an annual budget of $40,000.  This incredibly obtainable number can and will be reached through the profits from our bike shop, bike donations from the public and property management companies, collective membership dues, and monthly mini-fundraisers we can host on-site.  This sustainable funding model ensures that these initial infrastructure and program goals will be operating long into the future with zero additional funding.

For a detailed list of our 2015 programs and goals, please follow this link:

https://drive.google.com/open?id=0ByziRN46SnGwO...

Our Investment

Our initial investment to secure the building was $7,000.  We are in the process of using $15,000 to renovate and refurbish the inside of this beautiful space to maximize rent we'll receive. This will allow us to fully subsidize The Freewheel Project's rent and give us the freedom to put all future incoming monies back into the community through the funding of new or expanded programs.  Additionally, $5,000 will go into the rehab of the exterior (which is currently painted all black) in order to create a welcoming space that fits with the urban design and feel of the SoMa district.  Finally, we've budgeted approximately $2,000 to building our cross-crit track and cleaning up the exterior 2 acres and turning it into one of Gainesville's most sought after event spaces.

We’ve secured $36,500 in cash and in-kind donations from Board Member contributions, Community member donations, our merger with The Kickstand (Gainesville’s previous community bicycle project), a low interest loan, and bicycle donations from Pleasant Cyclery.

Your Investment

In a nutshell...

Your investment will go towards developing a long-term solution to the problem of accessibility and engagement in the cycling community.  Our plans for your investment include:

- building out our shop space and classroom

- buying tools, equipment, and inventory for our low cost bike shop 

- buying tool sets for our tool library and bikes for our bike library 

And if funds allow, purchase the bikes needed for Teen Freewheel Cycling (though we're actively seeking a corporate in-kind donation from a bicycle manufacturer).  

If we can't reach our entire fundraising goal it won't discourage us and it shouldn't discourage you.  We'll still get the wheel rolling.  Your investment will go towards insuring the sustainability of this project.  All funds will be put towards making the shop functional for service, sales, and education while also outfitting the collective with the parts needed to be successful.  As these aspects generate revenue, we'll be able to implement the projects and programs that we were not able to initially fund through this campaign. So, your investments foster further funding.  Think of yourself as a one-time, sustaining investor.      

Your contribution is vital to increasing the success and impact of The Freewheel Project.  Not only will we be a community resource for the 39% of Gainesville residents who live at or below the poverty line, we will also be a home for the cycling culture in all its variations.  Every dollar we raise goes back into the programs and services we provide, and we want to do a lot.  Help us build the dream and make cycling fun and accessible to everyone.

Frequently Asked Questions

We've provided some of the most popular questions posed to us:

1.  I'm ready to dig in and start helping now.  How do we help? 

We love your enthusiasm.  Everyone is welcome to come lend a hand during our current build-out process.  Our space is located at 618 S. Main St.  We’re here throughout the week during different times, but dedicated volunteer days are Sundays and Mondays. 

2. How do you become a member of the collective, what does it cost and what benefits does it provide?

The bike collective will provide countless benefits to cyclists of all ages and experience levels.  Collective memberships will run on a sliding scale from $50-$100 a year.  Once you become a member you gain access to our tool library so you can service your bike regularly using our dedicated tool kits and stands, it also gives you access to the bike library which will allow members to borrow some of the more cost-prohibitive luxuries such as tandems, trikes, cargo bikes, bakfiets up to 3 times a month.

3. I’ve got some older bikes and parts I’m not using, how do I donate them?

All donations are accepted either on-site at 618 S. Main St.  or at Pleasant Cyclery located at 235 NW 8th Ave. in beautiful Gainesville, FL.


Don’t forget to share this with EVERYONE!

story:
Orange Babies MONTESSORI PRE-SCHOOL is situated in Johannesburg South Africa.  It provides quality early childhood development (ECD) programs and education for children who are impacted by HIV/AIDS and/or who are from disadvantaged backgrounds. At the beginning of 2015 our main sponsor had to suddenly withdraw their financial support, due to their unexpected lack of cash flow.  The sponsor provided close to $50 000 on an annual basis.

This has left the school in dire straits. We need your help to keep the school operational for the next 18 months, to be able to find new sponsors, so that we can continue providing these vulnerable children with a fair and promising start to life. 

The Montessori approach to teaching allows us to address the issues underlying the trauma, pain and the mental challenges that some of the children are facing. The Montessori Program for our more than 90 children (age 2-6 years) helps them gain self-esteem, basic practical life skills, math/language skills and lays a strong foundation for the rest of their life. Our children perform very well when they begin primary school and many have gone on to receive certificates of outstanding behavior and performance at the next schools.

Our school has four classes with no more than 25 children per group, which enables the teachers to provide a nurturing learning environment. Each teacher has a teacher assistant. The school uses English medium and works with professional, certified teachers.

The income received from school fees just barely covers our operating costs and the costs for maintenance.  This is because the school fees have been subsidized so that parents can afford to send their children to the school. It is for this reason that additional flows of income and sponsors allow us to enhance the learning experience without making school fees unaffordable for parents. 

In order to be able to keep the school operational - whilst the board works extremely hard to find long term financial sponsors and solutions - your help will be much appreciated.

For more INFORMATION please visit:

http://www.orangebabiesmontessori.co.za/#

Thank you very much !!!

story:
WHO ARE THE TALIBE?


Talibé is an Arabic word, meaning disciple or student. It primary describes young boys between the age of 5 to 18 years. Most of them are sent by their families to the Marabouts (religious teachers), to study the Coran in a Daraa (School of Coran) in Senegal. These young children often stem from destitute families living in underdeveloped, rural areas and also neighbouring countries (Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, The Gambia, Mali). 

The majority of the Talibe children are living in a very precarious sanitary, health and nutritional situation, because the Marabouts do not take any care of them. Therefore they have to go into the streets to beg for food and money. Spend one day on the streets of St.Louis and you are guaranteed to encounter little boys, armed with empty tomato cans that they use as bowls for the food they receive. 



WHO ARE BEA?

BEA is a non profit association founded by young volunteers, who are conscious and frustrated of the suffering and grief situation in wich the Talibés live. Their ultimate goal is to eliminate this scourge. Therefore, they are working in sensibilisation of the affected parties, wich are the Talibés parents, the Marabouts and the Talibés themselves. The volunteers do not take any salary from the organisation and sometimes they have to use what little money they have to contribute towards medicine if there is a demand and shortage of supplies.


THE SITUATION

Many of the Talibe children have to sleep on the bare concrete and never have the luxury of blankets within the daraa, this results in infections like scabies which can be painful for the children and contagious. Also during the rain season in senegal malarial mosquitos are present, without mosquito nets the children are at a high risk of being bitten and infected.

There is currently one Daraa which doesn't have a toilet or shower for the children, this results in children living in a unhygenic enviroment which leads to more illness and infections.


OUR PROJECT

¤ Build a toilet and shower for one of the daraas
¤ Provide beds, sheets and mosquito nets for 5 Daraas
¤ Provide the children with new clothes and strong shoes
¤ Buy medicine to treat the children with illness and infections
¤ To start a community garden where free workshops will be given to the children so they can learn about agriculture in a savvanah climate.


WHAT WE NEED

We need to raise 3000 euros for all of our listed projects to be completed;


¤  €1500 will fund the construction of a toilet and shower for one school within the district Cite Niahk, Saint Louis. We need bricks, cement, wooden beams, plumbing fitures and paint to start this project.

¤  €500 will provide 10 schools with new beds, clean sheets and mosquito nets, also will cover cleaning products to keep the schools in a hygenic order.

¤  €500 will go towards starting a community garden in which free workshops will be given to children of the street and talibe children. We have the land and permissions to start the project, we just need the funds to buy tools and seeds to start planting.

¤  €250 will provide 25 children with new clothes and strong shoes for walking on the street.

¤  €250 will fund BEA's medicine supply so that we can help treat the children with infections and the childrens everyday cuts and bruises.

If we don't reach our goal of €3000 then we will focus on funding the projects that require less money like new clothes for the children and medicine supplies etc. So what ever you decide to donate will be used imediatly to help the children.

THE IMPACT

By funding this project whether it is a big or little sum of money, it will be greatly appreciated and will be put to use as soon as we have access to the funds to start the projects. We can help up to 500 children directly to live and study in a safe enviroment, the children will learn many different skills whilst living in the Daraas, like repairing clothes, cooking, cleaning, agriculture, the alphabet etc. 



OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you cant help with funding our project, dont worry! Even by talking to your friends and family about the Talibe children it creates awareness of their existence, or if you want to share our funding page on facebook or other platforms we will be very greatful! 

Thank you for your taking your time to read our pitch.

BEA

If you would like to find out more please check out our blog;

 http://beaafrique.tumblr.com/

Or if your interested in working with the BEA in Senegal Please Contact us via email;

 beaafrique@live.fr
